labels.value: Click "DETAILS" on the Status Card to view your status activity history. Take action on tasks that have been assigned to you or created by you or your delegate using the Open Task List. View study documents and other resources including articles and videos related to the study or the condition being studied from Resources.
Click Details to view more information about your participation in the study.

Click "My Study" to view the Study Workspace which includes information about the study in which you are taking part, such as inclusion and exclusion criteria and study site details. The expanded Tasks and Resources pages are also accessible from this area.
Click "Help" to access resources for guidance on using the portal.
Click on Study Name to see more details, such as inclusion/exclusion criteria.
Click on the "profile" icon on the top right of the page to manage your Account Settings including password and contact information, personal preferences, as well as Delegates.
If you have more than one role in the Referral Hub, you can easily switch between roles using the dropdown selector at the top right corner of the screen.
Add Team Members and Modify Permissions

Click on your user profile icon to access My Team. Add new members to your team by clicking on Add New Team Member. Manage an existing team member's permission for all studies by selecting a permission level and saving it on the team member's card.
Refer patients who passed the medical record review to the study site. Note that some studies do not require a medical record review.
View overall status of past referrals. Refer eligible patients directly from this page.

Click on your user profile icon to access Account Settings. In addition to managing your contact information, date and language preferences, and cookie settings, you can also choose the type of email notifications you want to receive. In the Email Preferences section, use the toggles to switch on or off the type of emails you want to receive. In the Referral Networks section, click Select Referral Networks to search and subscribe to institution-based and/or topic-based networks to be notified when a related study site or clinical study becomes available or to be contacted occasionally about related news or events.

labels.shortDescription: One or more Participants reached Majority
labels.value: One or more participants has reached the age of legal majority. Please confirm privacy preferences with participant(s).

Programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) is a protein that is found on the surface of many cells. Cancer cells sometimes have large amounts of this protein to help the cancer cells avoid the body’s immune system (your body’s natural defense system). This test measures how much PD-L1 is present on cancer cells. Some types of treatments may be more suitable for you if you have higher levels of PD-L1 present on your cancer cells. This test may help doctors predict which cancer treatments may work for you.

Platelets, also known as thrombocytes, are tiny parts of cells in the blood that are responsible for blood clotting. They made by your bone marrow and released into your bloodstream. When you are injured, platelets will help to stop the bleeding. The platelet count test shows the number of platelets you have in your blood sample. Platelet count is measured to check your general health and to check for any conditions that influence your body's platelet production. Low platelet count can be caused by certain cancers, chemotherapy, and in some autoimmune conditions.
Please confirm that your patient has signed ICF consent

Potassium is an electrolyte (a mineral) that helps to transport nutrients into cells and waste products out of cells. It also lets muscles and nerves to communicate with other muscles and nerves. Potassium is measured to check the balance of your electrolytes.

Red blood cells (RBCs or erythrocytes) are cells in your blood that contain hemoglobin, which carries oxygen throughout your body. RBC count is the total number of red blood cells that are present in your blood sample. RBC count is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your body's red blood cell production. Low RBC count can lead to signs of anemia, such as tiredness. High RBC count can cause dizziness and headache.

Upon registration, a delegate or provider added here will be able to view the participant's status in the study. Delegates can also see other participant information available via the Patient Portal. Unless the participant is a minor or otherwise requires a legal guardian, a delegate or provider should only be entered with the participant's explicit permission.

Sodium is an electrolyte (a mineral) that can be found in all bodily fluids. It is important for proper functioning of your muscles and nerves. Sodium is measured to evaluate the balance of your electrolytes.
Start Date should not be greater than end Date
Don't see a study that you could refer your patients to?

You will need to give some blood, which will be used to check your health and to see how your body responds to and processes the study medication. In the optional genetic research sub-study, blood samples will be used to see how genes affect the way the study medication works.

These are checks of your general health and may be brief or a complete examination. At the visits during the treatment period, you have a brief physical examination. This will include skin, lungs, heart and blood vessels, and abdomen. At the screening and follow-up visit, you will have a complete physical examination. This will include skin, heart and blood vessels, stomach and intestines, airways and neurological assessment (nerves), and any other necessary checks. Your height and weight will also be measured.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your chest to check the health of your lungs. You will have this test once between Weeks 48 and 51.

The study doctor will perform a procedure during which sticky pads are placed on your chest, arms, and legs. The pads are connected by wires to a machine that checks the rhythm and activity of your heart.
Before some visits, you will need to fast (not eat or drink anything, except water) for at least 6 hours before the visit.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your hands and feet to check the health of your joints.

An appropriately trained person (or doctor or nurse) will examine your joints and count how many are swollen and/or tender, by pressing on your joints with their fingers/hands. The pressing on the joints may cause some discomfort and pain for any joints that are tender.
This test will be performed to measure the amount of air you have in your lungs and how well you can move that air by forcibly blowing into a spirometer (lung function machine).

The study doctor will check the health of your lungs and any coughing by listening to the sound of your breathing with a stethoscope. They will also ask you about any breathlessness and measure the amount of oxygen in your blood.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
If you take part in contRAst-X, the long-term extension study, you will not have this follow-up visit.

If you are a woman who is able to get pregnant, you will have a pregnancy test at regular intervals during the study. The test at screening will be a blood test and the remaining tests will be urine tests. The effects of the investigational medication on unborn babies is not known.

You will be asked some questions about your health in general, your sleep, your pain and energy level, and how RA is affecting your daily life. There are also optional participant questionnaires, where you can provide feedback about your experience in the study.

You will speak to a member of the study team who will ask you questions about your health, any medications you have taken, and how you are feeling. This will happen every 1 to 4 weeks and may be done by phone or at the study center.
You will receive enough study medication to last until your next visit. You will also receive information on how to take and store the study medication.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
You will receive the study medication capsules every 4 weeks. You will also receive information on how to take and store the study medication.

You will receive the study medication injection at the study center. For visits at Study Weeks 0, 1, 12 and 13, you will need to stay at the study center for 1 hour after you have received the study medication injection. For visits at Study Week 3, 5–7, 9–11, 14, 15, 17–23, 25–35, 37–47, 49–51 you may be able to self-administer the study medication injection at home. Your study doctor will let you know whether this option is available. If you self-administer the study medication injection, you will receive a supply of pre-filled syringes every 4 weeks.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
You will be asked to provide urine samples, which will be used to check your health.
Your blood pressure, heart rate, breathing rate, and body temperature, will be measured.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your chest (to check the health of your lungs) and hands and feet (to check the health of your joints).

Please be aware that you will be redirected to the travel service setup and will need a travel service packet in order to complete the process. If you have not received a packet, travel support may not be available at your study center and you should check with a member of your study team.
By clicking OK, you are consenting to participate in the travel support service and leaving the IQVIA TM Patient Portal website. The Terms of Use and Privacy Policy on other websites may be different from those of this website. Please refer to the Privacy Policy and Terms of Use of these other websites as we cannot control or be responsible for their policies, terms of use, or legal/regulatory compliance.

Cholesterol is a type of fat made by the liver that is found in your blood. You can also take in cholesterol by eating certain foods, such as meat, fish, eggs, and dairy products. Your total cholesterol value is the sum of your low-density lipoprotein (LDL, or "bad" cholesterol) and your high-density lipoprotein (HDL, or "good" cholesterol).

Proteins are important for growth and development of the body by helping to make tissues and cells. The total protein test measures the total amount of two types of protein, albumin and globulin, in your blood sample. Total protein is measured to check the health of your liver and kidneys.

Triglycerides are a type of fat found in your blood. Your body uses triglycerides to give you energy. When you eat too many calories, your body will store these calories as triglycerides to use later. Most fats that we eat, such as animal fats and trans fats, are triglycerides. However, the body also produces triglycerides from the carbohydrates that we eat. When your triglycerides are high, they can build in the walls of your cells and block the blood flow, just like LDL cholesterol.

Triglycerides are a type of fat found in your blood. Your body uses triglycerides to give you energy. When you eat too many calories, your body will store these calories as triglycerides to use later. Most fats that we eat, such as animal fats and trans fats, are triglycerides. However, the body also produces triglycerides from the carbohydrates that we eat. When your triglycerides are high, they can build in the walls of your cells and block the blood flow, just like LDL cholesterol.

White blood cells (WBC or leukocytes) are cells that can be found in your blood and in body tissues that are important for your immune system (your body's defense responses). WBCs fight infections, cancer, and also remove poison, waste products, and damaged cells from your body. When you are fighting off an infection, the number of white blood cells increases. WBC count is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your body's white blood cell production. A high WBC count can mean you have an infection.
Your weight is the measurement of your body mass in kilograms (kg) or in pounds.
